publications.title: UR2: Ultra-rapid reactivity test for real-time, low-cost quality control of calcined clays
Use of Shear Wave Velocity to Evaluate Curing of Cement-Stabilized Carbonate Quarry By-Products at Different Temperatures
Reducing Pb and Cl Mobility in Waste-to-Energy Fly Ashes via Chlorellestadite Formation
publications.abstract: Sustainably sourced development minerals are vital to meeting the demand for low-carbon construction materials. A potential waste material that can be a cementitious systems is waste-to-energy fly ash (WTE ash), byproduct of incineration. WTE contains chloride-bearing species and heavy metals, which promote steel reinforcement corrosion present long-term leaching risks. Here, we new multistep treatment protocol involving dissolution heating transform nonreadily removable chlorides in chlorellestadite [Ca10(SiO4)3(SO4)3Cl2]. Our results suggest this transformation significantly reduces chloride release from an alkaline cement-like environment by over 2 orders magnitude, 1500 mg/L less than 10 mg/L. This also Pb mobility after (from >5 <0.5 mg/L), likely caused crystallo-chemical incorporation chlorellestadite. In contrast existing methods, proposed minimizes metals volatilization while simultaneously reducing through formation. These findings overcome limitations preventing commercial use thus opening up pathways toward circular economy.

publications.title: Automated estimation of cementitious sorptivity via computer vision
publications.abstract: Monitoring water uptake in cementitious systems is crucial to assess their durability against corrosion, salt attack, and freeze-thaw damage. However, gauging absorption currently relies on labor-intensive infrequent weight measurements, as outlined ASTM C1585. To address this issue, we introduce a custom computer vision model trained 6234 images, consisting of 4000 real 2234 synthetic, that automatically detects the level prismatic samples absorbing water. This provides accurate frequent estimations penetration values every minute. After training 1440 unique data points, including 15 paste mixtures with varying water-to-cement ratios from 0.4 0.8 curing periods 1 7 days, can now predict initial secondary sorptivities time high confidence, achieving R² > 0.9. Finally, demonstrate its application mortar concrete systems, opening pathway toward low-cost automated assessment construction materials. materials important durability. Here, authors method sorptivity paste, mortar, systems.

The then stabilized 3% cement subjected 7-day curing period, followed conditioning. publications.title: Phase quantification of anhydrous CSA cements: a combined X-ray diffraction and Raman imaging approach
publications.abstract: Calcium sulfoaluminate (CSA) cements are known for their special properties, such as shrinkage compensation and high early-age strength. These properties dependent on the hydrated phase assemblage, which in turn is governed by phases present initial anhydrous cement. However, CSA quantification X-ray diffraction (XRD) Rietveld can be challenging due to presence of overlapping peaks, polymorphs preferred orientation. To overcome this problem, an approach involving high-resolution large-area Raman imaging (5 mm × 5 mm, 250 000 pixels, with 10 μm/pixel resolution) complemented XRD analysis introduced. This integrated combined found crucial identification that a system. Most importantly, quantitative shows strong correlation (R 2 > 0.99) agreement (variation <5 wt%) between two independent methods, adding confidence reliability assemblage obtained dual-technique approach.

publications.title: Particle shape, crystallinity, and degree of polymerization of fly ash via combined SEM-EDS and Raman spectroscopy
publications.abstract: Coal fly ashes, long used as SCMs, are quite complex, consisting of a mixture crystalline and amorphous phases. In this study, we aim to shed light on complexity by fusing two highly complementary techniques: SEM-EDS Raman spectroscopy. By closely analyzing hundreds individual particles from 18 unique report major findings. Firstly, there is distinct correlation between particle shape (roundness/circularity) degree crystallinity (FWHM peaks) where jagged happen be almost always crystalline. Secondly, the mean position symmetric stretching band silicate tetrahedra (between 600 1000 cm−1) an indicator polymerization glassy phase in any given particle. These results highlight importance understanding these complex systems at level, multiple phases intermixed micro-scale ultimately play dominant role governing macro-scale ash behavior.

Silicon ion radiation as a viable surrogate for emulating neutron radiation damage in silicates
publications.abstract: Abstract Nuclear power plants are aging around the world, and a precise assessment of irradiation damage in their components is needed. One key component, concrete, specifically silicates its aggregates, can undergo significant expansion upon neutron radiation, which lead to cracking and, ultimately, structural failure. However, assessing predicting extent via radiation challenging due reasons such as residual radioactivity most importantly, high time involved. Here, we evaluate whether ion be viable surrogate. Specifically, by employing Si 2+ radiations comprehensive multi-modal imaging protocol, report mineral-specific responses for quartz, albite, anorthite, microcline. We find that 10 MeV ions result mineral expansions remarkably comparable equivalent (R 2 = 0.86, RMSE 1.29%), opening up pathways towards rapid subject irradiation.

Machine learning enabled orthogonal camera goniometry for accurate and robust contact angle measurements
publications.abstract: Characterization of surface wettability plays an integral role in physical, chemical, and biological processes. However, the conventional fitting algorithms are not suitable for accurate estimation wetting properties, especially on hydrophilic surfaces, due to optical distortions triggered by changes focal length moving drops. Therefore, here we present original setup coupled with Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) Contact Angle (CA). The developed algorithm is trained 3375 ground truth images (at different front-lit illuminations), less sensitive edges drops, retains its stability that synthetically blurred higher Gaussian Blurring (GB) values (GB: 0-22) if compared existing goniometers 0-12). Besides, proposed technique can precisely analyze drops various colors chemistries surfaces. Finally, our automated orthogonal camera goniometer has a significantly lower average standard deviation (6.7° vs. 14.6°) coefficient variation (14.9 29.2%) than techniques enables assessment non-spherical heterogeneous

publications.title: Rapid prediction of cementitious initial sorptivity via surface wettability
publications.abstract: Abstract The tendency of cementitious systems to absorb and transmit liquid through capillary pores is often characterized by initial sorptivity, which an important indicator long-term durability. However, sorptivity measurements, are based on the continuous mass change specimens exposed water, labor-intensive (up 6 h measurements). Here, we exploit fundamental surface-wetting characteristics estimate their in a rapid fashion, i.e., matter few minutes. In series 63 distinct paste varying w/c ratios (0.4–0.8), subject range curing periods (1–7d), establish strong correlations (adjusted R 2 ≥ 0.9) between (~6 h) dynamics drop spreading (contact angle ~0.5 s, residence time <10 min). These results elucidate pathways estimating durability broad variety hydrated matrices.

publications.title: Quantifying the global warming potential of low carbon concrete mixes: Comparison of existing life cycle analysis tools
publications.abstract: One of the most feasible approaches to reduce carbon footprint concrete, a critical contributor global CO2 emissions, is consider high-volume replacement cement with supplementary cementitious materials (SCMs). However, this approach currently has two issues: 1) low early-age strength, 2) inconsistent accounting. To address these issues, we investigate micro- and macro-scale performance series low-carbon concrete mixes analyze their warming potential (GWP) using 5 unique LCA tools. We report that cumulative heat, when normalized total water content, exhibits correlations key metrics such as open porosity (R2 = 0.83) compressive strength 0.92). In addition, all tools suggest high-SCM (55-70% replacement), broadly, can GWP values for by ~50% (from ~450 ~240 kg CO2-eq/m3). depending on mix tool used, values, relative variation be high 30% (~50-80 Finally, normalize metric an 'Integrated Strength Eco-Efficiency' (I-SEE) coefficient, which parameter simultaneously assessing concrete's environmental impact.

Elucidating the Size and Shape of Individual Clinker Phases via Raman Imaging: Impact on Cement Hydration
publications.abstract: Portland cement, produced at 4 billion tons/year, is a key ingredient of concrete─the world's most consumed material after water. The hydration and hardening cement upon reaction with water are greatly influenced by cement's chemical composition as well its overall particle size distribution (PSD). However, given that anhydrous cements composite mixture 8–12 chemically unique phases, the physical characteristics (size shape) these individual phases have not been fully explored in literature. Here, utilizing Raman imaging, we report, for first time, phase-specific PSDs shape all components set 10 commercially available diverse cements. By combining abundance, define composition-size quotient parameter (CSQ), which able to predict 72 h cumulative heat (R2 = 0.86)─a indicator performance, underscoring importance such characteristics.

Tracking spatiotemporal evolution of cementitious carbonation via Raman imaging
publications.abstract: Abstract Carbonation of cementitious systems is an important phenomenon from both durability (rebar corrosion) and greenhouse emissions (CO 2 sequestration) perspectives. Several analytical techniques are well‐established for measuring the kinetics this dynamic phenomenon, ranging pH change to quantifying calcite content over time. However, majority these methods (with exception electron imaging) rely on bulk measurements which may miss fine, microstructural changes that occur during carbonation. In study, we investigate evaluate potential Raman imaging follow spatiotemporal evolution carbonation in pastes. By analysing mm‐scale maps (1 mm × 1 mm) at micron‐scale resolution, find nearly ~40% sample surface was covered with end a 2‐week exposure. Simultaneously, portlandite declined ~15% 5% same period, suggesting consumption sake growth. Finally, difference between growth rate strongly suggests simultaneous CSH ettringite—a finding agreement recent experimental investigations kinetics. Overall, new results microstructure pave way utilizing understanding phenomena complex systems.

publications.title: Ultra-high gamma irradiation of calcium silicate hydrates: Impact on mechanical properties, nanostructure, and atomic environments
Impact of Na/Al Ratio on the Extent of Alkali-Activation Reaction: Non-linearity and Diminishing Returns
publications.abstract: To address the high CO2 footprint associated with cement production, many alternative, sustainable binders are now gaining worldwide attention-including alkali-activated materials. The alkali-activation reaction of metakaolin is a fairly complex process involving transformation one amorphous reactant (precursor metakaolin) into another product or products (N-A-S-H gel and/or disordered zeolite type phases). In spite this complexity, researchers in past 2 decades have gained significant knowledge on nature at multiple scales. Understanding and developing clear relationship between alkalinity mix extent interest for practical applications. However, detailed thorough investigations important limited. Here, study, we gap by systematically investigating series materials samples wide range Na/Al ratios (0.5-1.8) using seven different yet complementary analytical techniques (isothermal calorimetry, FTIR, XRD, TGA, NMR, Raman imaging). Applied tandem, these tools reveal but non-linear ratio indicating diminishing returns higher ratios, where cause an increase degree until certain point which does not significantly affect kinetics, may polymerization. These findings could potentially aid decision making commercial applications AAMs parameter performance as well safety.

publications.title: Superhydrophobic and Self-Cleaning Aluminum via a Rapid and Controlled Process
publications.abstract: Superhydrophobic and self-cleaning materials have been an extensive topic of research owing to their corrosion resistance, antifouling, anti-icing properties. In the past, superhydrophobicity in aluminum has obtained by a variety techniques involving etching sandblasting, chemical etching, boiling water, etc. followed treatment with fluorochemical organic solution. However, these are not controlled, might be easy implement on large scale, mostly make use fluorochemicals, which risky for human health environment. Therefore, there is need rapid controlled fabrication process that can provide patterned without compromising environment or health. Here, rapid, environmentally friendly procedure fabricating superhydrophobic surface developed, achieving contact angle 158.06° sliding 1.94°. two-step process, rough was using laser technique under 3 min, resulted precisely pattern dual-scale roughness (∼20–30 μm). Finally, low energy imparted stearic acid where concentration 2 × 10–4 M no more than 10 s exposure found sufficient. Unlike various superficially coated materials, this durable does lose its properties after dipping water up 4 days, encountering fine sand mud, at extreme surrounding temperatures −18 100 °C. Thus, obtaining potentially deployed large-scale, structural applications.

publications.abstract: In physical sciences such as chemistry and earth sciences, specifically for characterization of minerals in a rock, automated, objective mapping methods based on elemental analysis have replaced traditional optical petrography. However, mineral phase maps obtained from these newer approaches rely conversion compositions to mineralogical thus cannot distinguish polymorphs. Secondly, techniques often require laborious sample preparations sectioning, polishing, coating which are time-consuming. Here, we develop new Raman imaging protocol that is capable unpolished samples with an auto-focusing Z-mapping feature allows direct fingerprinting different Specifically, report methodology generating high fidelity by exploiting characteristic peak intensity ratios can be extended any multi-phase, heterogenous system. Collectively, enhancements allow us rapidly map granite specimen (~ 2 × mm) exceptionally accuracy (> 97%) extremely fine spatial resolution (< 0.3-2 µm).

publications.title: Nanoscale Ordering and Depolymerization of Calcium Silicate Hydrates in the Presence of Alkalis
publications.abstract: Increasing cement production and its substantial contribution to anthropogenic CO2 emissions (∼5–8%) have led the pursuit of alternative, sustainable cements. These cements often contain non-negligible amounts alkalis (Na or K) which significantly influence resulting material's performance. publications.title: Properties of self-consolidating concrete containing high-volume supplementary cementitious materials and nano-limestone
publications.abstract: AbstractIn the present paper, conventional self-consolidating concrete (SCC) incorporating 40% Class F fly ash (FA) replacement for cement, and semi-flowable (SFSCC) FA 15% metakaolin (MK) with or without 1% nano-limestone (nanoLS) addition, were studied. Properties of fresh mixtures, such as air content, slump flow, J-ring flow tested. hardened concretes, compressive strength, rapid chloride permeability, freezing–thawing resistance, free drying shrinkage examined. The results indicated that SCC mixture displayed good workability adequate strength (33 MPa) at 28 days. In addition to enhancing (especially early ages) durability, MK also improved shape-holding ability SFSCC. Addition nanoLS further increased resistance reduced permeability.Keywords: ashmetakaolinnano-limestoneself-consolidating concretesemi-flowable AcknowledgmentThe authors would like acknowledge Oak Ridge Associated Universities (ORAU) – Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA), USA, sponsoring study (Grant No. 7-22976).
